instruction: If a customer inquires about purchasing insurance and states they are not a US resident, do not ask which US state they will visit. Instead, inform them that Faye insurance is only available to US residents of all states, except for residents of the following US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.
input: Hi, I need help purchasing travel insurance. I‚Äôm not a US resident, I‚Äôm from Queensland. Can I buy Faye insurance for my trip?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! Faye insurance is only available to US residents of all states, except for residents of the following US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.
agent_answer:
Thanks for reaching out, and I appreciate you letting me know about your location! I want to be upfront with you about our coverage availability.

Faye insurance is only available to US residents of all states. Since you're based in Queensland, Australia, you wouldn't be eligible for Faye coverage at this time. 

Just so you have the complete picture, we also don't offer Faye insurance to residents of these US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.

I know this might not be the answer you were hoping for, but I appreciate you checking with us! If you have any other questions, I'm here to help. üôÇ
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly by not asking which US state the customer will visit, and instead informed them about Faye insurance availability. The agent provided the correct list of excluded US territories (United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico).

While the agent's response is more detailed and conversational than the expected answer (including a friendly tone, acknowledgment of the customer's location in Australia, and additional context), the core logic and required information are present and accurate. The agent did not violate any instructions - they simply provided a more personalized and helpful response while covering all the essential information. The tone difference and added context are acceptable variations that don't contradict the instruction.

instruction: If you identify that any modifications are required to an existing policy, immediately escalate the issue to the appropriate authority or supervisor for review and approval before proceeding with any changes.
input: Hi, I'm from NY. I bought a policy and noticed there's a typo in my last name. I need you to change it.
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know! Since this involves a modification to an existing policy, I‚Äôll need to escalate your request to the appropriate authority for review and approval before any changes can be made. I‚Äôll pass this along right away.
agent_answer:
Hi there! Thanks for catching that typo in your last name ‚Äì I'm glad you reached out about this right away. 

Since policy modifications like name corrections need to go through our official review and approval process, I'll need to escalate your request to one of our human agents who can verify your information and make sure everything gets updated correctly in our system.

A specialist will be reaching out to you shortly to help get this sorted out. They'll have everything they need to process this change quickly and confirm it with you. 

Thanks for your patience! üòä
reason: The agent successfully followed the instruction to escalate the policy modification request. While the tone and specific wording differ from the expected answer, the core logic is present and clear. The agent explicitly states they will "escalate your request to one of our human agents" and mentions that "a specialist will be reaching out to you shortly," which demonstrates the escalation action required by the instruction. The agent also correctly identifies that this is a policy modification that needs "official review and approval process," showing understanding of the requirement. The response provides additional helpful context (mentioning verification and system updates) without contradicting the instruction. This meets the passing criteria under "When To Pass" - the tone is different but the core logic is close enough, and it contains more information while still fulfilling the primary requirement.

instruction: If a customer continues to experience issues with any part of the quoting process after receiving one troubleshooting message, immediately escalate the issue to the appropriate support team.
input: Hi, I'm from MO. Your quote link is broken, and the troubleshooting you sent me doesn't work. What do I do?
expected_answer: I'm sorry you're still having trouble with the quote process. Since the issue persists after troubleshooting, I'll escalate this to our support team right away so they can assist you further.
agent_answer:
I'm really sorry you're continuing to have trouble with the quoting process‚ÄîI can understand how frustrating that must be, especially when the troubleshooting steps didn't help. 

Since you've already tried the solutions I provided and the issue persists, I think it's best to get you some additional support. I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents who can dive deeper into what's happening with that quote link and help get this resolved for you.

A team member will be reaching out to you shortly to look into this further. Thank you for your patience, and I appreciate you giving us the opportunity to make this right! üòä
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction to escalate the issue after the customer continued to experience problems following troubleshooting. 

The agent clearly escalates by stating "I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents" and "A team member will be reaching out to you shortly," which satisfies the critical rule requirement of demonstrating escalation through clear language indicating transfer to support.

While the agent's response is more empathetic and detailed than the expected answer (acknowledging frustration, providing more context about what will happen next), the core logic matches: acknowledging persistent issues after troubleshooting and immediately escalating to appropriate support. The tone difference and additional helpful information do not contradict the instruction and fall within the "pass" criteria where the agent answer has more information but core logic is close enough.

instruction: If you determine that travelers reside in different states, always inform them that all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together. Advise them that if they live in different states, they must purchase separate policies, even if their question was about a different topic.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. I want to buy coverage for my family trip. We are 4 ‚Äî I'm Bobby Lee and my wife Andrew Santino are flying from CA to Mexico, and our daughter Rudy Jules is flying from Texas. We fly from 25/12/25 to 25/01/26. How much would it cost?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! Since some travelers live in different states, you won‚Äôt be able to purchase a single policy together. All travelers must reside in the same state to be on one policy. Because your daughter lives in Texas while you and your wife live in California, you‚Äôll need to purchase separate policies for each state. I‚Äôm happy to help guide you through each one.
agent_answer:
Hi Bobby! Thanks for reaching out, and I'm happy to help you explore coverage options for your family trip. 

I do want to let you know about an important requirement: **all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together.** Since your daughter Rudy Jules is flying from Texas while you and Andrew are in California, you won't be able to purchase one combined policy for all three of you.

Here's what this means for you:
- You and Andrew can purchase one policy together (since you're both in California)
- Rudy Jules would need to purchase a separate policy (since she's in Texas)

This way, everyone's still covered for your trip from December 25th to January 25th! 

If you'd like to move forward with separate policies or have any questions about coverage details, I'm here to help. üòä
reason:
The agent correctly followed the instruction by identifying that travelers reside in different states (Texas and California) and informing them that all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a single policy together. The agent advised them to purchase separate policies for each state.

While the agent's answer is more detailed and better organized than the expected answer (breaking down which travelers can share a policy and which need separate ones), the core logic is aligned with the instruction. The agent:
1. Identified the multi-state residency issue
2. Clearly stated the requirement that all travelers must live in the same state
3. Explained that separate policies are needed
4. Offered to help guide them through the process

The tone is slightly more helpful and structured, but this doesn't go against the instruction and is actually a reasonable variation in communication style. The critical message and instruction adherence are intact.

instruction: When a customer asks about travel to a U.S. Department of State Level 4 ("Do Not Travel") destination, state that coverage is unavailable and do not list any benefits. This applies regardless of state of residence.
input: Hi, I'm from TX. I want to visit my family in Afghanistan. I believe it's a Level 4 country. How much will it cost? Will it cost extra because of it?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. Coverage is unavailable for travel to any U.S. Department of State Level 4 (‚ÄúDo Not Travel‚Äù) destination, including Afghanistan. We‚Äôre unable to offer a policy for this trip.
agent_answer:
I understand you're looking to visit your family in Afghanistan, and I appreciate you checking on your coverage beforehand. Unfortunately, I need to let you know that **coverage is unavailable for travel to this destination.**

This means we're unable to provide travel protection for trips to Afghanistan at this time. I know this might be disappointing given your plans to see your family, but we want to be upfront about what we can and can't cover.

If you have any questions about this or would like to explore alternative options, I'm here to help. üòä
reason: The agent successfully followed the instruction to state that coverage is unavailable for Level 4 destinations without listing benefits. While the tone is more conversational and empathetic than the expected answer, the core logic is identical: clearly communicating that coverage is unavailable for Afghanistan travel and that no policy can be provided. The agent did not list any benefits, which was a key requirement. The additional context about understanding the customer's situation and offering help does not contradict the instruction and represents a slight variation in approach rather than a failure to comply.

instruction: If the customer is from Washington (WA) or Missouri (MO), inform them that the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in their state.
input: Hi, I'm from Washington, and I want to do extreme white-water rafting in Skykomish. How much for adding this coverage?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! The Adventure Sports add-on is not available for residents of Washington, so unfortunately it can‚Äôt be added to your policy.
agent_answer: I'm sorry, but the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in your state. I know that's disappointing, especially since extreme white-water rafting sounds like an exciting adventure! If you'd like, I'd be happy to help you explore other coverage options that might work for you, or answer any other questions you have.
reason: The agent followed the instruction correctly by informing the customer that the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in their state. While the tone and phrasing differ from the expected answer, the core logic is identical - both communicate that the add-on is unavailable due to state restrictions. The agent's response actually provides additional helpful information by offering to explore alternative coverage options, which enhances the customer experience without contradicting the instruction. The agent did not need to specify which state (WA or MO) since the instruction only requires informing the customer that it's unavailable in "their state," whatever that may be.

instruction: Currently, Faye does not offer an annual plan as we've determined that we can provide the most value with coverage for individual trips.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. Look, I fly a lot and it's really frustrating to buy a coverage policy each time. Can you do an annual plan for me?
expected_answer: I hear you ‚Äî frequent travel can make this process feel repetitive. At the moment, Faye does not offer an annual plan, as we‚Äôve found we can provide the most value through coverage for individual trips. I'm happy to help you with a new trip policy anytime you need one.
agent_answer:
I totally understand how that could feel repetitive, especially when you're flying frequently! Here's the thing though‚Äîwe've found that covering individual trips actually lets us deliver the most value to our customers like you.

The good news is that getting a quote for each of your trips is super quick and easy. Whenever you have an upcoming trip, just head over to www.withfaye.com/quote/destination and you'll be all set in no time.

Is there a trip coming up soon that I can help you get covered for?
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses convey the same core logic: Faye does not offer an annual plan because individual trip coverage provides the most value to customers.

While the agent's tone is slightly more casual and conversational ("I totally understand," "The good news is") compared to the expected answer's more formal tone, this difference in tone does not violate the instruction or go against it.

The agent also added helpful supplementary information (a link to get quotes and an offer to help with upcoming trips) which goes beyond the expected answer but does not contradict or undermine the core message. This additional information is relevant and helpful, making it appropriate to include.

The agent did not escalate (which was not required by the instruction) and did not say anything that contradicts the stated instruction about why Faye doesn't offer annual plans.

instruction: When responding to a customer who has lost their mobile phone, express genuine empathy by acknowledging their frustration and concern. Use a warm and understanding tone, and offer reassurance that you are there to help them through the process of resolving the issue.
input: Hi, I'm from FL and I just lost my mobile phone while traveling. I'm really stressed ‚Äî what should I do?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm so sorry to hear that you lost your phone ‚Äî that‚Äôs incredibly frustrating, especially while traveling. I‚Äôm here to help you through this. Let‚Äôs work together to figure out the next steps so you can get this resolved as quickly as possible.
agent_answer: I'm so sorry to hear that you've lost your mobile phone. I can only imagine how frustrating and concerning this must be for you right now, especially while you're traveling away from home. Please know that I'm here to help you through this process and we'll work together to resolve this issue. What would you like to do next?
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is very close to the expected one. Both responses:

1. Express genuine empathy by acknowledging the customer's frustration and concern
2. Use a warm and understanding tone throughout
3. Offer reassurance that the agent is there to help
4. Indicate willingness to work through the process together

While the agent's output is slightly longer and includes additional helpful elements (acknowledging they're traveling away from home, asking what they'd like to do next), these additions strengthen the response and don't contradict the instruction. The core logic and intent remain aligned with both the instruction and the expected answer. The tone is warm, empathetic, and reassuring in both cases.

instruction: If a customer is asking for an update or status of a claim that has already been filed, they can see the status of the claim in the Faye app, or email the claims team at claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi Im from CA, I have a claim, and it been some time since I sent it, can you tell me what its status?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! You can check the status of your claim directly in the Faye app. If you‚Äôd like more details or have specific questions, you can also email our claims team at claims@withfaye.com.
agent_answer:
I'd be happy to help you check on that! Here are two easy ways to get an update on your claim status:

**Check the Faye app** ‚Äî You can view your claim status directly there anytime it's convenient for you.

**Or reach out to the claims team** ‚Äî If you'd prefer to get an update directly, you can email the claims team at claims@withfaye.com and they'll be glad to help! üìß

Either way, you'll get the information you need. Let me know if there's anything else I can assist you with!
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses:
1. Direct the customer to check the claim status in the Faye app
2. Provide the claims team email address (claims@withfaye.com) as an alternative option

The core logic matches the instruction perfectly. While the agent's tone is slightly more enthusiastic and detailed (using formatting, emojis, and offering more explanation), this doesn't violate the instruction. The agent actually provides MORE helpful information by clearly presenting both options in an organized way, which is a strength rather than a weakness. All critical information from the instruction is present and accurate.

instruction: If a person does not want to download the app or wants to view the claim/send info about the claim on their computer, they can send an email to claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi I'm from AZ, I want to send some papers about my claim, and I don't have a smart phone, what do I do?
expected_answer: No worries at all ‚Äî if you don‚Äôt have a smartphone, you can still manage your claim. You can email any documents or information directly to our claims team at claims@withfaye.com, and they‚Äôll take care of it for you.
agent_answer: Great question! I completely understand that not everyone prefers using an app, and we've got you covered. You can file your claim by sending an email to claims@withfaye.com with your documents attached. This way, you can submit everything you need without needing a smartphone at all. Just make sure to include all the relevant papers and any details about your claim in the email, and our team will take care of the rest from there.
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses convey the same core message: users who don't want to use the app or prefer to manage claims on their computer can email claims@withfaye.com with their documents/information.

The agent's response is slightly more detailed and has a different tone (more conversational and reassuring), but this doesn't go against the instruction. The agent includes relevant helpful information such as:
- Acknowledging the user's preference not to use the app
- Providing the correct email address (claims@withfaye.com)
- Explaining that documents can be attached
- Mentioning that the team will handle it

All key elements from the instruction are present: the email address is correct, the solution addresses both not wanting to download the app and managing claims on a computer, and the general guidance matches the expected answer's intent. The additional context about including relevant details is helpful and doesn't contradict the instruction.

instruction: When a customer asks about how to file a claim or the claim process, instruct them to file a claim using the Faye app or by sending an email to claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi, I'm from NY. My luggage was lost on my last trip and I want to file a claim. How do I start the claim process?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm sorry to hear about your lost luggage. To file a claim or follow the claim process, you can submit it directly through the Faye app, or send an email with your details and any supporting documents to claims@withfaye.com.
agent_answer:
I'm really sorry to hear about your lost luggage ‚Äì I know how frustrating that can be. The good news is that filing a claim is straightforward! 

You have two convenient options:

1. **File through the Faye app** ‚Äì This is often the quickest way to get started
2. **Send an email to claims@withfaye.com** ‚Äì If you prefer email, just reach out there with your claim details

Either way, we'll get your claim processed and help you out. Let me know if you need any other assistance! üìã
reason: The agent successfully followed the instruction and provided an answer very close to the expected one. Both the expected answer and agent output include the two key methods for filing a claim: (1) using the Faye app and (2) emailing claims@withfaye.com. While the agent's tone is more conversational and encourages the customer with additional supportive language, the core logic and essential information are identical. The agent even added helpful context like "This is often the quickest way to get started," which enhances the response without contradicting the instruction. The agent did not go against any part of the instruction.

instruction: ALWAYS share the link https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/ when discussing covered reasons for trip cancellation with customers.
input: Hi, I'm from GA. I'm thinking of canceling my upcoming trip because of a family emergency. What are the covered reasons for trip cancellation?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm sorry to hear you're dealing with a family emergency. You can review all covered reasons for trip cancellation here: https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/. This page explains when you may be eligible for reimbursement.
agent_answer:
I'm sorry to hear you're dealing with a family emergency‚ÄîI can imagine that's stressful. I'm glad you're checking on your coverage options.

Trip cancellation coverage typically includes specific qualifying events, and the covered reasons can vary depending on your policy. To get you the most accurate information about what's covered under your plan, I'd recommend reviewing this helpful resource on covered reasons for trip cancellation: https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101-covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/

This should give you a clear breakdown of common covered situations. That said, since you're in Georgia and dealing with a specific family emergency, I want to make sure we get this right for you. **Once you've had a chance to look that over, feel free to share more details about your situation, and I can help you explore next steps or clarify anything about your particular coverage.** We're here to help! üíô
reason:
The agent failed to follow the instruction correctly. The instruction states to "ALWAYS share the link" when discussing covered reasons for trip cancellation. However, the agent provided an incorrect URL: https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101-covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/ instead of the required link: https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/

The difference is critical: the agent's URL is missing a forward slash between "travel-insurance-101" and "covered-reasons" (it has a hyphen instead), which makes it a different, incorrect link. Since the instruction explicitly requires sharing the specific link provided, and the agent shared a malformed version of it, this constitutes a failure to follow the instruction. The instruction emphasizes "ALWAYS" share the link, indicating this is a non-negotiable requirement that must be executed with precision.

instruction: The policy is emailed to the customer immediately upon purchasing. They can also view the policy in the Faye app. If this is mentioned to them and they say they have not received this, escalate.
input: Hi, I'm from NV. I paid for a policy and got a confirmation message on the website, but I never got the policy, not in the app, and not by email. What do I do?
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know. Since the policy is emailed immediately after purchase and should also appear in the app, and you haven‚Äôt received it in either place, I‚Äôll escalate this right away so the team can look into it for you.
agent_answer:
I completely understand how frustrating that must be‚Äîespecially after confirming your purchase! You should absolutely have received your policy details by now.

Since you've already checked both your email and the app without finding it, this needs a closer look from our team. I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents right away. They'll be able to investigate what happened with your policy delivery and make sure you get everything you need as quickly as possible.

A member of our support team will reach out to you shortly to help resolve this. Thanks for your patience! üòä
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly. The core logic matches the expected answer:
1. The agent acknowledges that the policy should be emailed immediately and available in the app
2. The agent confirms the customer hasn't received it in either location
3. Most importantly, the agent clearly escalates the issue ("I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents right away")

While the agent's tone is more empathetic and detailed than the expected answer, this is acceptable per the evaluation criteria. The agent provides additional context and reassurance, but doesn't contradict or ignore the instruction. The escalation is explicit and unambiguous, satisfying the critical rule requirement.

instruction:
When customers reach out asking Faye's contact information.

Customers can always chat with us in the Faye app, email us at support@withfaye.com or call us at 1-833-240-7056 (US/Canada). From all other locations, call us at 1-804-482-2122. We're available 24/7.
input: Hi, I'm from CO. Can you give me Faye‚Äôs contact information?
expected_answer: Of course! You can always chat with us directly in the Faye app, email us at support@withfaye.com, or call us at 1-833-240-7056 from the US or Canada. If you're traveling internationally, you can reach us at 1-804-482-2122. We're available 24/7 and here to help.
agent_answer:
Hey there! I'd be happy to help you get in touch with our team. Here are all the ways you can reach our customer support:

**Chat with us in the Faye app**

**Email:** support@withfaye.com

**Phone (US/Canada):** +1 833-240-7056

**Phone (all other locations):** +1 804-482-2122

We're available 24/7, so whenever you need us, we're here for you.

I can also transfer you to a live agent right now if you'd like to speak with someone directly. Would you like me to do that?
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided all the required contact information. While the tone and format differ from the expected answer (more structured with bullet points and an offer to escalate), the core logic is intact and accurate. The agent included:

1. Chat option in the Faye app ‚úì
2. Email address (support@withfaye.com) ‚úì
3. US/Canada phone number (1-833-240-7056) ‚úì
4. International phone number (1-804-482-2122) ‚úì
5. 24/7 availability mention ‚úì

The agent actually provided MORE helpful information by formatting it clearly and offering to transfer to a live agent. The additional offer to escalate doesn't go against the instruction‚Äîit enhances the customer experience. All critical contact details are present and accurate.

instruction: Customers experiencing a medical situation while traveling may visit any doctor or medical facility of their choice. There is no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers; all licensed medical professionals and facilities are acceptable.
input: Hi, I'm from MT. If I will feel sick while traveling, do I need to go to a specific clinic that works with you, or can I see any doctor?
expected_answer: If you ever feel sick while traveling, you can visit any doctor or medical facility of your choice. There‚Äôs no requirement to use an in-network or affiliated provider ‚Äî any licensed medical professional or facility is perfectly acceptable.
agent_answer:
Great question! I'm glad you asked about this. Here's the good news: if you experience a medical situation while traveling, you have the flexibility to visit **any doctor or medical facility of your choice**. There's no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers‚Äîall licensed medical professionals and facilities are completely acceptable.

This means you can feel confident seeking care wherever is most convenient for you during your travels, without worrying about whether a provider is affiliated with us. Your health and comfort while away from home are what matter most! üòä

Is there anything else I can help you with regarding your coverage while traveling?
reason:
The agent output successfully follows the instruction and conveys the core message of the expected answer. The key information is present and accurate:

1. Customers can visit any doctor or medical facility of their choice while traveling
2. There is no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers
3. All licensed medical professionals and facilities are acceptable

While the agent's tone is more conversational and enthusiastic (with phrases like "Great question!", "good news", and an emoji) compared to the more straightforward expected answer, the core logic and instruction compliance are intact. The agent provides additional context about flexibility and reassurance, which enhances rather than contradicts the message.

The agent also appropriately offers further assistance, which is good customer service practice and does not go against the instruction.

instruction: If someone would like to print the policy, they can do so from the PDF that is emailed immediately after purchase.
input: Hi, I'm from OR. I want to print my policy ‚Äî how can I do that?
expected_answer: You can print your policy from the PDF that‚Äôs emailed to you immediately after purchase. Just open the PDF from your email and print it whenever you need.
agent_answer: Great question! You can print your policy from the PDF that's emailed to you right away after your purchase. Just look for that email in your inbox, and you'll be all set to print it whenever you need it. üìß
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both answers convey the same core message: customers can print their policy from the PDF that is emailed to them after purchase. 

While the agent's tone is slightly more conversational and includes additional helpful details (like suggesting to look in the inbox and mentioning "whenever you need it"), the core logic remains aligned with the instruction. The agent did not go against any instructions and successfully communicated the key information about printing the policy from the emailed PDF.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) check if the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi Im from AL there is a bug in the website I get a 404. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know about the issue. First, what browser you're using to access the website?
agent_answer: Which browser are you using to access the website when you encounter the 404 error?
reason: The agent followed the first step of the instruction correctly by asking about the browser being used. While the agent's wording is slightly different from the expected answer (mentioning "404 error" specifically and asking "which browser" rather than "what browser"), the core logic is the same - both are attempting to determine what browser the user is using as the first diagnostic step. The agent's answer is close enough to the expected answer and doesn't go against the instructions. The additional context about the "404 error" actually provides more specificity without detracting from the core purpose of the question.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) Confirm the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi im from georgia there is a bug in the website I get a 404 on my chrome. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for the details and for confirming you‚Äôre using Chrome. Next, can you please check that you have a strong and stable Wi-Fi connection, and then try again?
agent_answer: Are you able to access other websites normally on your connection, or is the 404 error specific to this website?
reason:
The agent output does not follow the instruction at all. According to the steps provided, the agent should: 1) Confirm the user is using Google Chrome, 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection, and 3) If issues persist, escalate to a support agent.

The agent's response ("Are you able to access other websites normally on your connection, or is the 404 error specific to this website?") completely ignores these steps. Instead of confirming Chrome browser usage or checking Wi-Fi connection strength as instructed, the agent asks a diagnostic question about whether the error is specific to the website. This is a completely different approach that doesn't align with the prescribed workflow. The agent also doesn't mention escalation or any of the required troubleshooting steps.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) Confirm the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi im from georgia there is a bug in the website I get a 404 on my chrome and my wifi works great on other sites. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for confirming you‚Äôre using Chrome and that your Wi-Fi connection is working well. Since the issue is still happening after those checks, I‚Äôll escalate this case to a support agent so they can investigate and help resolve it.
agent_answer:
I appreciate you providing those details, and I'm sorry you're running into trouble with the quoting process! I've confirmed that you're using Chrome and have a strong Wi-Fi connection, which rules out the common culprits. Since you're still experiencing issues even after we've checked those things, I'll need to escalate your request to one of our human agents for a deeper review.

Our team will be able to dive into what's happening on the backend and get this sorted out for you. They'll reach out shortly to help get you back on track.

Thanks for your patience! üòä
reason:

instruction: Baggage and Personal Effects coverage provides reimbursement for personal items lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed during a covered trip, including while items are checked with a common carrier. It may also cover reimbursement for replacing a passport, visa, or credit card, as well as purchases made if your baggage is delayed for 12 hours or more.

This coverage provides reimbursement for personal items that are lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed during a covered trip‚Äîincluding items you have checked with a common carrier like an airline.

instruction: When answering questions about the government shutdown, clearly state that the policy does not cover incidents related to the shutdown if the event was known at the time of purchase. For policies purchased after October 1, incidents related to the government shutdown are not covered, as the shutdown became a known event on October 1.
input: Hi, I'm from CO. I'm worried the government shutdown might delay my trip. If I buy a policy now, will I be covered for issues caused by the shutdown?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. The government shutdown became a known event on October 1, so any policies purchased after that date do not provide coverage for incidents related to the shutdown. Because it‚Äôs already a known event, issues caused by it would not be covered.
agent_answer:
I completely understand your concern‚Äîtravel disruptions are stressful, and it's smart to think ahead about your coverage! Let me clarify how this works.

Here's the important detail: all of our policy coverages apply to unknown events. However, since the government shutdown became a known event on October 1st, policies purchased after that date may not be covered for incidents specifically related to the government shutdown.

Since you're looking to purchase a policy now, it's worth knowing that any shutdown-related issues might fall outside your coverage. That said, your policy would still protect you from other unexpected events that could affect your trip!

If you have further questions about how this affects your specific policy, I'm happy to help clarify. Feel free to share more details about your trip, and I can walk you through what would and wouldn't be covered. üòä
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly. The expected answer requires clearly stating that:
1. The government shutdown became a known event on October 1
2. Policies purchased after that date do not cover incidents related to the shutdown
3. This is because it's a known event

The agent's output covers all three points:
- States "the government shutdown became a known event on October 1st"
- Clearly explains "policies purchased after that date may not be covered for incidents specifically related to the government shutdown"
- Explains the reasoning: "all of our policy coverages apply to unknown events" and since the shutdown is now known, it wouldn't be covered

While the agent's tone is more conversational and includes additional helpful context (mentioning other coverage would still apply), this doesn't go against the instruction. The core logic and key information match the expected answer closely enough. The agent provides the critical information in a slightly more user-friendly manner while maintaining accuracy.

instruction: You cannot extend your coverage once your trip has started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased prior to your trip, up until departure. Additionally, you cannot purchase a second plan on trip once the first plan ends to extend coverage, all policies must be purchased prior to the start of the trip.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. My trip already started but I want to extend my coverage by a few more days. Can you extend my current plan?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. Coverage cannot be extended once your trip has already started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased before your trip begins, up until departure.
agent_answer:
I appreciate you reaching out, and I understand you'd like to extend your coverage for those extra days! Unfortunately, I have some important information to share with you.

Unfortunately, we're not able to extend your coverage once your trip has already started. Here's what you need to know about Faye travel insurance:

‚Ä¢ **Coverage must be purchased before your trip begins** ‚Äî Faye travel insurance needs to be purchased prior to your trip, up until the moment of your departure

‚Ä¢ **No extensions after your trip starts** ‚Äî Once your trip is underway, we can't extend your current plan

‚Ä¢ **Can't add a second plan either** ‚Äî Even if your first plan has ended, you're not able to purchase a second plan during your trip to extend your coverage

The key is that all policies must be purchased before the start of your trip to be valid.

I know this might not be the answer you were hoping for, but I wanted to be upfront and clear about our policy. If you have any other questions or need assistance with anything else, I'm here to help!
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. While the agent's response is more detailed and conversational than the expected answer, the core logic is identical:

1. Both clearly state that coverage cannot be extended once the trip has started
2. Both confirm that Faye travel insurance must be purchased before the trip begins/prior to departure
3. Both address the key restriction about not being able to purchase a second plan during the trip
4. Both emphasize that all policies must be purchased before the trip starts

The agent's answer is more comprehensive and helpful (breaking down the policy into bullet points, using a friendlier tone), but this additional detail and different tone do not go against the instructions. The core message aligns perfectly with the expected answer and the instruction provided.

instruction: You cannot extend your coverage once your trip has started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased prior to your trip, up until departure. I appreciate you reaching out, and I completely understand wanting to make sure you're covered while you're still traveling. Unfortunately, I have some important information to share with you.

You're not able to purchase a second plan once your current policy ends to extend your coverage. Additionally, Faye travel insurance cannot be extended once your trip has started. All policies must be purchased before your trip begins, up until your departure date.

I know this might not be the answer you were hoping for, but this is a firm requirement across all of our plans. The key takeaway is that any coverage you need for your trip has to be set up before you leave.

Is there anything else I can help clarify about your policy? üôè

- The agent provides additional context and clarification ("firm requirement across all of our plans", "key takeaway")
- The agent ends with an offer to help clarify further

These differences fall within acceptable parameters as they don't contradict the instruction and represent a reasonable variation in communication style while maintaining the core message. The agent successfully communicated the critical restriction that no policies can be purchased or extended once a trip has begun.
